entry.title: RPT-1, Document AI, Perplexity in AI Core and co. - How to start your 2026 right with SAP's AI offer
entry.content:
AI remains years after its new wave of generative AI more omnipresent then ever in our daily lives and there not a single day passes where we don't talk about new announcements, AI ethics discussion, if it is a bubble, what amount of money is spent and so on. For those of you, who follow me, will know, that I preach all day that the key to successful AI adoption is a useful case, the right technology and working with the people.

Writing prompt guidelines is just enablement for another side-by-side tool and does not gain efficiency rather joy trying out new things. Building an agent for a pretty deterministic process might be fun and easy to implement, but expensive and unpredictable in production. And so on... While many are talking about large mainly American software vendors with their "agentic foundation killing any SaaS", SAP's offerings might not be so familiar to you (besides Joule and BDC) - so that's my motivation to provide a sneak peak of exciting topics in 2026.

Use Case: Onboarding of a new vehicle to the car fleet

In order to make tools tangible and understand the bigger picture, we will sketch an AI-assisted process of vehicle onboarding. Previously following steps were mandatory:

  1. Clerk typing vehicle data into system from the official vehicle document
  2. Vehicle Master Data Engineer adding additional information based on public search as required drivers licence and consumption values
  3. Finance expert to determine the tax amount to be paid for that year based on manual and local review
  4. Field Service Manager classifying the vehicle for the right purposes to be used

As you can see, this process is slow, very labor-intense and quite possibly error-prone. We will now step-by-step automate this by leveraging different AI tools offered by SAP within the Business AI portfolio 🙂

Our ultimate goal is creating a low-code-first, enterprise-ready automation to avoid manual research and typing into the system:

 

Capturing of correct data: No more manual data entries from 2026 on

If you have in 2026 tasks which require typing in data from one medium (e.g. mail or paper) into your system, it's time to automate this asap. In our scenario, we do have the vehicle document on paper, as this one:

Instead of typing this, we use the SAP Start app on our iPhone to take a picture and the deep integration to SAP Document AI to process this document (see more here). We then utilise Document AI with our custom schema to extract the results and preview these to our clerk for a double-check. Instead of building entire new UIs, workflows, etc. we can now do this directly in Document AI and get a nice view of the document on the left and extraction on the right:

 

Automating web searching: Leverage the perplexity integration in SAP AI Core

SAP AI Core is the central hub for any access to MLOps activities and GenAI. With your BTP account you have access to a wide variety of partner models hosted on hyperscaler infrastructure and SAP's very own one with Mistral. If you didn't know this yet, that we have an orchestration workflow with prompt optimiser and much more, look up here which models we offer through your BTP contract.

Lately, we have added Perplexity as well - the AI-assisted search engine. Now we can connect publicly available data straight into our workflows, and it's huge, e.g.

  • classify the purchased non-catalog item to the correct product group
  • fill gaps in master data based on product sheets
  • make research on sustainability KPIs of your supplier
  • conduct analysis for B2G processes
  • get market macro trends or real-time insights, e.g. supply chain disruptions
  • ...

We will leverage the Perplexity integration to enhance our vehicle master data by the required drivers licence type for Swiss drivers licences and the energy consumption according to WLTP (an industry standard to measure consumption). We can model our prompt in SAP AI Launchpad and use the prompt registry to save it with placeholders:

And now it's so simple to add it to your pro-code app via CAP, to your low-code automation in SAP Build Process Automation or your integration flow in SAP Integration Suite:

In this iFlow you can see how we leverage the new outbound channel feature in Document AI to enrich the extraction of the results straightaway with an iFlow exposed via API management (for more, stay tuned on upcoming webinars). If you have seen in the previous screenshot of Document AI - there is a tab with "Z - additional values" 😉

Do machine learning without data scientist: SAP's own foundational model RPT-1

Now we have been onboarding our vehicle, but we must classify for which tasks we can use it. Luckily we have already quite a large fleet and some data. Ideal for machine learning (yes that's also part of AI and yes AI is not only GenAI).

Machine learning learns from historical data - as simple as this is, this requires a data set, model fitting, model validation and deployment. Not straightforward. With Gemini, Le Chat and co. we are used to just prompt AI models. What if, we could just put a snapshot of our table to a pre-trained model and let it classify by itself. Congrats - you are now a RPT-1 user:

RPT-1 has its own playground, is accessible via AI Core and is phenomenal for transactional classification and prediction tasks. If you want to know more about its integration, I'd recommend you this gem. In my scenario, we use RPT-1 in our workflow in Build Process Automation to classify our vehicle correctly before we post it to our equipments in S/4HANA:

Performing more agentic tasks: Joule Studio

Previously you might have heard, you can use Joule Studio to make Joule truly yours. Joule Skills are intent-based automations made familiar to Joule to perform tasks conversational based. They can leverage workflows, pro-code and integrations via Integration Suite.

2025 Christmas gift, was the GA of the agent building capability in Joule where we can model agents. Agents are behaving non-deterministic and trying to mimic a human thought by providing it a scene and background - like an improvisation theatre. Now it's oftentimes pretty tricky to understand when an agent is really necessary. In our example we use an agent to determine how the vehicle tax are calculated for the Kanton St.Gallen, where we have registered our car and perform a calculation based on the perplexity web search (disclaimer - this can be modelled through a workflow in Build, it's just for the sake of simplicity):

 

Why choose SAP for your AI journey?

That's a good question and especially given there are soooo many tools on the market, why should you? It's simple: it's all about enterprise readiness. Behind every of this automation, there is only 5-10% AI, the remaining parts are security, audibility, traceability, transport management, scale resiliently in production, monitoring, low-code modelling etc. And for all of the remaining bits and pieces, SAP BTP has always been the best option from SAP Build to SAP Integration Suite. With SAP Document AI, we have a leader in document processing with inbound and outbound channels, and SAP AI Core a powerful AI orchestration service at low costs each.

While you can get other services cheaper somewhere, the TCO of this toolbox is imho astonishingly low. And for building this scenario from mobile device intake to equipment in S/4, I just needed a day to configure and build without pro-code needed. Happy AI-2026...

entry.title: DIGITAL TWIN TECHNOLOGY FOR PROCESS OPTIMIZATION
entry.content:
1.     Introducing the State of the Art

The current state of virtualization of real-world processes in different industries is characterized by domain-specific solutions, single-siloed approaches and therefore shows a splintered and fragmented landscape across domains. Although virtualization is used everywhere but not harmonized, the discussion of actual technologies and the value of holistic integration of those virtualization technologies into a future generation of Digital Twins is intended to boost the application of those Digital Twins and is therefore considered to be key to real value generation. Diverging streams of activity in research, industrial trends and standardization efforts result in slow adoption. Those diverging streams lead to a higher perceived risk for today’s offerings as well as fear of missing out on future offerings and with that ultimately to slower adoption.

The outlined hypothesis here is that autonomy needs to reach a threshold level together with a harmonized approach of integration and autonomy to provide real value to process optimization. Key objectives are the meta structure of a holistic digital twin and the achievable improvements by integration for several realistic industrial scenarios.

Not within scope of this paper are the implications of this concept for the technologies and applications relevant for the holistic digital twin. Further analysis will be required to understand the impact on runtime environments, platforms, and networks. We address the actual situation by taking different viewpoints on the topic and further identify the challenges with the traditional approach.

 

a.     Digital Twins and their interaction with other functional elements

How do elements of a future digital twin concept support today relevant functionalities of control and interaction.

The article examines the combination and application of AI, Generative AI, and Digital Twins in the context of process management. It specifically focuses on the development of Agentic AI components and the "Data as a Product" philosophy. Figure 1 illustrates the current state: AI as well as generative AI, and digital twin technologies coexist and operate side-by-side without true integration and orchestration, which is the starting point of our evaluation.

 

Figure 1 AI, GenAI, and Digital Twin components

Agentic AI and human collaboration

Agentic AI enabled software sees the start of early market introduction according to Gardner [1] and other sources.

Topics of human and agent collaboration like control, interaction, and directives are addressed by research as well as software industry to focus on specific value creation and to fulfill requirements by the EU AI Act. (see [14])

We understand that research postulates (see [8]) the active digital twin empowered by agentic technologies. This can be considered as important first step to reach a much higher level of functionality for Digital Twins.

 

b.    Digital Twins and their semantic descriptions

Publications are available to describe the general concepts of the Asset Administration Shell (AAS), its different types, and their implications [2].

The Platform Industry 4.0 [3] had started the development and standardization efforts many years ago and has initiated and accompanied the foundation of the Industrial Digital Twin Association [4] as user organization to execute standardization in international organizations (e.g., International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC)) as well as to promote the technology in different industries. Resulting from this work, the AAS has been included in the IEC series of

Promoting Digital Twin technology by software companies and by automation industry is closely related to driving internal standardization. This is motivated by enablement of common semantics and effective information exchange between applications within their respective portfolio. Those industry driven custom standards are vendor specific, for internal use only, and seldom accessible via public interfaces (see [15] in example).

Developments in research focus more on how to extend the capabilities of Digital Twins. Data integration, real-time analytics, interoperability and artificial intelligence are the key words here. Standardization is not a real focus of academic research.

As of today, we see an unbalanced approach between academic and industry. The limited cooperation focuses mainly on cooperation in publicly funded projects and organizations.

Additionally, we see regionally different approaches in research: While research in North America is targeted at the full simulation of the physical object, there is a strong focus on semantics and standardization in Europe (see [15] which highlights the use case perspective of digital twin technology vs. [3] and [4] which focus on providing public standards and motivate to apply those standards to the portfolio of asset providers).

This leaves the supplier and operator sides in manufacturing with open questions: How to create the required Digital Twins? Do we make them or buy them? How to create tangible value by implementing and using them?

In favor of all said above, the market size for Digital Twins is estimated to reach USD 110.1 billion by 2028 with at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 61.3% [5]. So there is enough reason to act now and drive the evolution of Digital Twins to create real industrial manufacturing benefits.

 

c.     Industrial processes and Digital Twins

Process optimization is mainly referred to as IT-supported optimization of business processes. But what about technical processes which are fundamental that is, part of the core process of manufacturing, and are optimized with engineering- and maintenance-based applications and tools?

These two types of processes have not yet been considered in the same context. Namely, how can a Digital Twin optimize across business and technical processes?

We see value in having a more aligned approach between these two types.

 

Business Processes

Business Process Management (BPM) supports digital transformation in a static manner and provides expertise on existing process landscapes. Adaption and optimizing business processes is up to now a human or “manual” task and with limited focus on new or emerging technologies where efficiency is driving the product roadmap rather than innovation.

Agentic optimization of business processes is rather a research related task with first commercial initiatives in the open-source community [5], [6].

 

Technical Processes

Technical processes are governed and maintained by process engineering with limited IT support and more human based experiences and skill sets.

The technical process contains process descriptions like BPM but in addition requires specific recipes, quality management guidelines, and regulations. Representation of those additional information is well understood by research and proven and well-established (e.g., by Colored Petri Nets (CPN), Systems Theory etc.).

 

d.    Challenges for virtualization with Digital Twins

However, the separated approach to those different process types above result in low adoption and lead to major roadblocks in intercompany collaboration or, in the best case, to adapting Digital Twin technology only for the main product strategies.

Local adoption, that is in manufacturing, might lead to local optima and might only push any bottleneck further down the process chain. In addition, Digital Twin technology so far has no importance in the context of digital transformation, which is primarily seen as a predictive and deterministic exercise on value chains. But these value chains are more and more based on processes which cross the borders of a single corporation and require a networked implementation in between companies - internally for cooperations and externally for business networks.

The financial view of Digital Twins represents the asset as a capital expenditure (CAPEX) object in financial reporting and the respective financial platform. This is still an isolated topic and not considered in the context of process optimization, but assets need to be integrated with their financial representation as well, in order to represent a holistic view of the full business value.

In summary, current Digital Twin initiatives are fragmented on one side across domains (technical vs. business processes) and on the other side fragmented between research vs. industry vs. standardization efforts, leading to slow adoption and suboptimal value generation. This underlines the need for a holistic integration,which we address next.

2.     Proposed Holistic Digital Twin Framework

To address the lack of integration between business and technical processes, the HDT combines both process types in a single model. To enable autonomy, which will address the need for a certain threshold of autonomy mentioned earlier, we incorporate Agentic AI components. To deal with semantic interoperability issues, we leverage the Asset Administration Shell standard within the HDT for common data descriptions.

Therefore, we present here a generalized model of a next-generation holistic Digital Twin system, which addresses the open gaps and challenges outlined before. This model shall describe Digital Twins relevant for technical as well as business processes. This model is then validated in several real-worlds scenarios from different industries.

We follow a conceptual approach by first defining the principles of an HDT Architecture, then evaluating this approach against three distinct real-world scenarios taken from the fields of manufacturing, pharmaceutical production and inter-company business networks, in order to illustrate its applicability and benefits. Here we identify the desired achievements with this conceptual approach. The Holistic Digital Twin (HDT) system is based on paradigms and will need further innovation on topics we will clarify here.

 

The holistic paradigm

We talk about something being “holistic”, if the elements are designed in such a way that the total collection will be able to exceed the individual performances of the respective elements of the entire collection.

The next generation of Digital Twins are Holistic Digital Twins (HDTs), which include data, control, sensors, and actuators and therefore will be able to generate intelligence and behavior within a defined scenario.

 

The self-similarity paradigm

 

The HDT composes system elements which exposes three characteristics: asset, capability, and replication and are self-similar with respect to these three characteristics. Self-similarity will lead us to less hierarchical technical systems, as they will turn into heterarchical[4] systems with higher adaptability and autonomy.

 

a.     Components and structure

We outline the major components and elements involved in this conceptual approach and highlight the interaction and collaboration with external elements of the software landscape.

Being self-similar requires covering three elements:

  1. The description of the asset
  2. The description of its capabilities
  3. The description of the capability to replicate this very asset

These elements characterize a Digital Twin of the next or second generation. The actual technology for Digital Twins is always based on physical assets which are connected to a virtual description. The next generation of Digital Twins will have the capability to exist without a physical asset and can generate physical assets based on their inherent descriptions and capabilities.

It deemed important to outline that the HDT as representative of a 2nd generation of digital twins provides capabilities to generate a 3rd generation of digital twins, where autonomy and interaction between 3rd generation twins create autonomous behaviour of a swarm representing many digital twins.

 

Figure 2 The next generations of Digital Twins

 

The Holistic Digital Twin (HDT) as outlined here represents the second generation for following reasons:

  • The term process here also includes technical processes. Therefore, a plant HDT can produce a product HDT.
  • The capabilities generate such replication based on self-similarity. A production plant consists of assets and process descriptions. The resulting asset “product” itself consists of the asset description as well as the complete description how to produce it.
  • Production systems consist of products which in turn are produced on other production systems.

This picture illustrates why it is important to understand technical and business processes both as processes and describe them in same methodology of self-similarity) (see Figure 3 Self-similarity of assets as requirement for self-replication.

 

 

Figure 3 Self-similarity of assets as requirement for self-replication

 

A real holistic system evolves when all key capabilities are bundled, are identified as one object, and can communicate amongst each other with focus on their domain of interest. Therefore, we suggest a Holistic Digital Twin Framework as outlined in the next chapters.

 

Figure 4 : A Holistic Digital Twin (HDT) – Architecture showing the core components of the HDT (e.g., User Interface, AI Engine, Data Integration, Process Management)

 

User Interaction and Interfaces

Visibility into the HDT must be ensured to understand workflow and actions inside of the HDT, implemented by using dashboards. Control of the HDT is a must to secure against misuse, understand hallucination and bias, and prevent wrong outcomes. Control is tightly connected to the security and governance layer.

API-encapsulted capabilities implement two different scopes. One scope deals with access to tool landscapes which are important to enable the HDT to act within a given frame and to invoke applications. The other scope deals with standard API functionality which enables the HDT to interact within the IT landscape.

 

Digital Twin Core

Data models deal with the traditional efforts of semantic standardization. The Industry 4.0 Platform initiated the development of the Asset Administration Shell (AAS) as semantic standard which is maintained by the International Digital Twin Association (IDTA) (see [2]and [4]). Important are also custom specific semantic standards which are defined, often as proprietary standard, by individual companies. A discussion of standardization is contained in chapter 4.b below as one of the main drivers for market penetration with Digital Twin technology.

Simulation models are at the core of generative AI and allow to affect future actions of the HDT based on learning and prediction. Results are stored in dedicated and persistent storage of the HDT.

Both data and simulation model work hand in hand. Data models extend the accessible data foundation and simulation models improve the quality of data models.

The synchronization engine is essential to handle the different elements of technical process descriptions, which range from formalized elements like process notations or recipes to informal elements like GXP. Those regulations are defined by different national and international regulation bodies, where we refer to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA (www.fda.gov) or the European Medicines Agency (EMA, https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/homepage )  for pharmaceutical processes.

 

Data Ingestion and Integration Layer

Any information about the real world and the informational world needs to be collected as raw data and passed through infrastructure like edge devices or edge software and finally distributed in middleware layers before the digital twin core can digest and execute this information.

Important to mention is that this refers to a production environment where IoT data is key to understand the real world as well as to information technology where data contained in business applications is computed before transmitted to higher levels of the architecture.

 

AI and Analytics Engine

Machine learning, Large Language Models (LLM), and decision logic provide the intelligence to perform the critical tasks of the HDT:

  • Break down a function into different tasks
  • Analyze the available information
  • Develop a solution strategy
  • Learn from execution
  • Support persistency to improve the function

The degree of autonomy of the HDT and the communication via user interfaces are controlled here based on user regulations and rules.

Such alignment needs interaction between different elements of the HDT like the AI and Analytics Engine, the Synchronization Engine, and the Access Control of the Security and Governance Layer.

 

Process Management and BPMN 2.0 Integration

This element of the HDT is the second most important one (besides AI and Analytics Engine) as it interprets, harmonizes, and generates a common view on technical processes as well as business processes.

The capability to understand business process notations, to maintain a set of best practice processes, and to generate and communicate modified and new business processes is based on today’s standard notations with Business Process Management Notation (BPMN) 2.0 [12].

The capability to describe technical processes needs to include the description of the asset itself, the processes related to this particular asset and the terms and regulations being relevant for the asset[6].

Further research needs to be done to define a common machine-readable semantic for both types of process descriptions.

 

 

Access Control as part of the overall control of this Agentic-AI-driven HDT is required to ensure validated and protected data access. Access Control implements data policies and provides protection against hostile attacks towards the HDT.

Encryption is relevant to ensure data protection and secure transmission of information.

Logging and Audits are important to prevent cybercrimes, support forensic analysis on ongoing or past attacks.

The security and governance layer in its entirety suggests considering compliance and to be the foundation for implementation of AI ethics in accordance with the EU AI Act regulations. The focus needs to be the risk evaluation of the potential use of the HDT.

b.    Expected Contributions

We identify here what contributions this approach will provide for the future architectural landscape of industries. We discuss its potential implications, applications, and how to further advance understanding and drive deployment.

 

Integrated Value proposition

We expect to contribute with value propositions on different levels or layers which are compiled in this  Figure 5 :  Integrated Value Proposition for Digital Twin Technology in Process Automation.

Those layers are not necessarily architectural layers but individual topics being put in a holistic frame. All layers represent a value chain in itself and are based on core technologies. Layer 1 enables a data lifecycle which is enabled by the HDT holding the relevant data for each product. In Layer 2 cooperation between research and standardization bodies will be put on a new foundation by integrating the processes of real-world applications. On layer 3 autonomy will be introduced in a more safe manner.

 

Figure 5 :  Integrated Value Proposition for Digital Twin Technology in Process Automation

 

Point of View – Autonomous behavior and human control

 

 

Point of View - The balance between Research, standardization and real-world application.

The HDT conceptual approach of a Digital Twin has the capability to describe Digital Twins for all three initiatives. Find more in chapter 4.b with further explanations.

 

Point of View – Data with a Product Lifecycle

It is mandatory to define a data foundation, where lifecycle management of the desired data products can be established. This is already provided today in concepts like data fabric, but the HDT will be able to really unfold the value of this foundation. This follows the holistic paradigm as described in chapter . Find more in 4.a with further explanations.

 

Point of View – the Central Core: The Integration Model

The holistic approach of HDT will drive the application of standardization efforts like AAS (or other related standards) as semantic standards by adding the Agentic AI capabilities and a rule-based system to achieve autonomy and supervision for the scenarios of operator-type customers in their industries.

The meta-model of HDT encompasses also the internal standardizations of supplier-type companies, because the Large Language Models (LLM) as implementation of models allow to adapt to all kind of semantic standards.

 

Point of View – the Ethical Aspect: The European AI Act

We consider here the ethical discussion in the light of how to provide or deploy in accordance with the EU AI Act.

Fundamental for the EU AI Act is the risk assessment, where high-risk AI systems (HRAIS) need to be either excluded or clearly indicated as such by provider and deployer with obligations for both. The HDT is derived in its nature from an asset, which usage in the context of this paper is likely to be non-high risk related. Nevertheless, all elements marked as “Controlled Interaction” in the picture Automation serve the purpose of fulfilling requirements of risk management, transparency, documentation and human governance.

Autonomy of the HDT is a key differentiator from other software systems in accordance with the EU AI Act. Therefore, it must be controlled through user interaction (governance, transparency, and documentation).

In HDT, the intended usage as required by the EU AI ​​Act is virtually enforced through the risk assessment by embedding the AI ​​system and the analytics engine, since the entire HDT is not general purpose but serves to describe and create a specific asset (thus supporting well-defined risk management).

 

Redefined Modularity and Composability

The HDT is basically a meta model to describe actual Digital Twin approaches. It exceeds actual state of the art with the holistic paradigm which collects and describes all relevant intelligence within the frame of HDT to fulfill a real-world scenario and redefines the concept of modularity.

Therefore, the traditional horizontal approach in architecture design will be extended or even replaced by such meta model and a related composable architecture.

 

3.     Impact to Process Automation

We summarize here the illustrative scenario analyses of our thought leadership approach. It is important to highlight that this is a theoretical evaluation of the concept. With reference to the industrial scenarios, we highlight how the Holistic Digital Twin concept improves our view on process optimization and open doors to the next generation of holistic digital twins. Highlighting significant conceptual patterns will be based on diverse point of views.

 

a.     Application in real-world scenarios

We will evaluate now the capabilities of an HDT based architecture in different industrial processes scenarios to illustrate its versatility and benefits

 

Scenario - Modular production in manufacturing industries

Main characteristics of modular production are similar or at best equal to production modules with a shift of intelligence from higher levels of Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) and Maintenance Executions Systems (MES) into the production module itself. The term module applies to the actual manufacturing steps (cutting, welding, assembling, etc.) as well as to the enabling logistics components like Automatic Guided Vehicles (AGV)[7] or logistic controls. Manual reworks stations will follow this same principle.

This definition of the term modular production is taken from a real implementation in 2024:

The organizational form of modular production is characterized by three central basic principles: decoupled stations, a self-organized production system and an integrated overall system. [6]

On an abstraction level a modular production could look as in Figure 6 : Automation components to implement a modular production . A characteristic is the the capability of each element to serve multiple purposes like producing or transporting a variance of different products. : This is combined with a clear separation between transport of material and manufacturing of material, all connected with the external production by inbound and outbound logistics.

 

Figure 6 : Automation components to implement a modular production

 

The main characteristic of modular production is to enable higher flexibility in variant production by balancing demand and capacity with decentralized intelligence on the involved modules.

We are representing each of these modules as a HDT and will evaluate the advantages of HDT compared to the actual still centralized intelligence implemented by logistic control and by work order management.

We anticipate the existence of one HDT for each of the elements in modular production like one HDT representing one of the modules and one of the AGVs

If we look at the processes required to execute this modular production we take for example the actual manufacturing-related processes, as described in Figure 7 : Manufacturing Processes in Modular Production. Supporting processes are the manufacturing control, Quality Assurance and Control and Maintenance & Repair. These processes are suggested here to be executed by each module, which requires capabilities of autonomy and intelligence, which will be enabled by the HDT.

 

 

Figure 7 : Manufacturing Processes in Modular Production

 

Some processes require execution by the matrix module, others require that the matrix module needs to contribute (with information), and for some processes the matrix module itself requires information.

This will significantly reduce the complexity of supporting applications like MES and optimize usage of production system by improving white space management[8].

This will require multiplication of intelligence to the different Module x, but will reduce complexity since the concept requires the very same intelligence on all module x.

The same logic will be applied to the material transportation units AGV x.

In addition, this approach allows the HDT embedded intelligence to predict the production capacities and provide a forecast on produced units per time unit. This is relevant as modular production is sometimes criticized for being behind linear production in capacity targets, although more advanced in adaptability to varying demands.

No central control system is required with an HDT based production planning, which reduces overall cost and increases flexibility.

The value proposition of a HDT for a matrix module is positive only under the condition, that the HDT-Matrix Module can execute the indicated parts of the three business processes, manufacturing, quality assurance & control, and maintenance & repair. The guidance and orchestration of the Matrix Module is provided by the production planning & scheduling process. The key value proposition is the direct execution of sales orders, the real time-based Inventory and order management resulting in faster customer value.

This scenario demonstrates how distributing intelligence via HDTs to each component like modules or AGVs can eliminate the need for central control efforts and reduce the overall complexity of the production system.

 

Scenario - Low volume production

The pharma production in life science industries tends to outsource production of active pharma ingredients (API) to Contract Development and Manufacturing Organizations (CDMO) as third parties. This requires a gap analysis between the required technical processes to produce the API and the technical capabilities of the CDMO plant. This gap analysis includes technical solutions (processes like lithiations or cryogenic processing to mention a few) as well as chemistries (chemicals like acid chlorides, bromination, nitration etc.).

This gap analysis can be improved by HDTs which represents the APIs on one side by including also recipes and technical process requirements and on the other sides HDTs representing the capabilities of the production system owned by the CDMO and exemplarily shows self-similarity in real life.

Self-similarity of HDTs is a pre-condition to efficiently execute this gap analysis. The HDTs shall be able to support the decision if a defined technical process can be executed on a given production asset and to maintain the information during the life cycle of product and production.

Another benefit of the HDT framework here is that the pharmaceutical industry can also provide simulations about what would have happened if an intervention would not have happened (e.g., a process change would not have been implemented, or a medication would not have been taken); this might come in particularly handy to demonstrate progress/success if not easily visible (e.g., treatment that can’t cure an illness, only slow it down etc., so adherence to the therapy is crucial (e.g., Alzheimer)).

This matching of requirements to capabilities can up to now just be done as a manual work which depends on the knowledge of those doing it.

The key door opener is the self-similarity paradigm which enforces on a meta level the one-to-one comparison of two different HDTs representing the product and the production system.

Both are being compared on asset and on process level. This will drive efficiency in selecting CDMO for the major stake holders in pharmaceutical industries.

This shows the power of the HDTs self-similarity paradigm in matching process requirements to production capabilities, a task that currently is manually executed and therefore often inefficient.

 

Scenario - Business network data exchange

Business becomes networked business between companies which is based on decentralized business networks, where control, decision-making, and resources across multiple participants is distributed rather than controlled by a single authority.

The exchange of data requires up to now a major implementation effort for participating companies regarding the topics of usage, transfer, validity, and ownership.

Data as a self-explaining and self-authorizing data product can be implemented as a HDT. This HDT can be exchanged between decentral networks and contain all relevant processes to validate their usage. With data completely described via HDT, Data-as-an-Asset will help create real and transparent data marketplaces and overcome the asymmetric interest in data between data holders, data users etc . (see [23]).

Interoperability between open industry specific data spaces is under development[9] (see [27]). Those business networks are supported by external standardization efforts for semantics like the Asset Administration Shell (AAS). The critical topic for those decentralized networks is governance of such network. The data being exchanged between different network members contains so far just data, rules of usage and indications of ownership.

The critical question under discussion is the semantics of the data and the governance of the entire business network.

The HDT has the capability to exchange “Data as a Product“, where each of those products is represented as a HDT. The advantage is that no central governance of a network is required because the HDT provides governance all by itself. No business network is required anymore, as the HDT has the capability to carry with it all the necessary metadata, usage rules, and verification mechanisms.The holistic paradigm of the HDT allows the receiving business partner to evaluate the HDT represented data product and to evaluate its usage and fitness for purpose

In addition, the semantic standard being used with this “Data as a Product” is part of the capabilities descriptions. Understanding the content of the data product will be supported by all the efforts of external and internal standardization as described in the chapter Re-balancing standardization.

Since this scenario requires the clearest “Data as a Product” approach, we highlight in more detail how the HDT support this scenario.

 

Figure 8 : The lifecycle of “Data as a product” in AI, Generative AI and Digital Twins Integration with a HDT

 

We anticipate that the entire data lifecycle is covered from data creation, data curation and management to data packaging and distribution. All these steps are supported by HDTs through a semantic rule-based system which provides access to a common set of meta data and documentation.

This scenario highlights the potential of HDTs to enable trust-worthy data sharing without a central broker, by encapsulating data and its governance within the Data-as-a-Product digital twin.

 

 

b.    Re-balancing standardization

Standardization is a precondition for any interoperability of HDTs provided by the same or different suppliers. Therefore, this is relevant for all three considered real-world scenarios.

We see the different efforts on semantic standardization for Digital Twins of generation 1 being drifting apart on the supplier side as well as on the side of international standardization bodies.

Major companies representing the supplier side are driving the Digital Twin technology by laying an internal semantic foundation to promote Digital Twin technology and accept these semantic standards and solutions only to be-used within their own portfolio.

External standardization as common effort by many companies is organized by standardization bodies and organizations. They need to identify the common agreements on mainly semantic details and therefore will always be in such development behind the market requirements.

These both streams of technological developments need to be in balance in order create real progress in digital process optimization.

 

Figure 9 : Illustrative positioning of HDT in balancing research, standardization, and practical deployment

 

This entanglement of internal standardization with external portfolio growth (in terms of market share) hinders the operator-side companies in driving their digital transformation based on a solid data foundation and intelligent use of AI technologies.

The concept of the HDT as proposed here supports both types of standardization efforts by following a holistic and self-similarity-based approach. This is driving the development of both types of standardization and will push forward adoption of digital twin technology. Operator-side companies will benefit from this new approach of standardization by releasing the obstacles for their digital transformation.

 

 

4.     Conclusion and Outlook

Based on the evaluation of the scenarios, we review the results in the context of actual ongoing developments.

This paper introduces a concept for a next generation Holistic Digital Twin, which provides a meta-model to depict actual concepts for Digital Twins and open doors to new functionalities and business opportunities in virtualization. It also provides a solid base to enable environments and platforms for holistic – and autonomous – digital twins of second and third generation.

The Holistic Digital Twin model eliminates the conflict between semantic standardization and the impressing business potential for virtualization with Digital Twin technology. This will enable process optimization for networked inter-company as well as cross-company collaboration.

Combining intelligence with information is the underlying idea of the HDT and makes the HDT independent and autonomous. This is in accordance with the holistic paradigm. Value creation of such strong capabilities happens by following self-similarity paradigm, which removes hindering separations between products, assets, and intellectual properties. Actual developments in the open-source community already show how to combine capabilities by crossing the border between different applications. Further subject of research will be how to implement and create the next generation of HDT´s to enable intelligent systems.

Within the scope of this article, we focused on the entire conceptual picture. Understanding how to adapt existing technologies and applications would provide valuable insights. Validation within prototypes and real-world scenarios will remain scope of future work.

Future architectures will be built upon modular, autonomous, and agentic software, thus the Holistic Digital Twin will provide the optimal foundation for such software.

 

 

5.     References

 

 

 

[1] IEC 63278-1 ED1 project "Asset administration shell for industrial applications - Part 1: Administration shell structure"

[2] IEC TC65 WG24

[3] See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-similarity

[4] Heterarchy describes a decentralized organizational model in which the various subunits of an organization are not in a relationship of superiority or subordination to one another but are largely equal.

[5] GxP is a collective term for a set of "good practice" guidelines and regulations used in the life sciences industry to ensure the quality and safety of products such as pharmaceuticals, medical devices, and food. The "X" stands for various areas such as GMP (Good Manufacturing Practice), GLP (Good Laboratory Practice), GCP (Good Clinical Practice), and more.

[6] Further examples are given in chapter 17, where we outline the application in different industrial scenarios.

[7] AGV – Automatic guided vehicle as component of a modular production to enable material, tooling and product transport in between different production modules.

[8] Whitespace Management – Optimal alignment of maintenance & repair and planned idle time of production system

[9] Manufacturing-X and Catena-X are examples of industry specific business networks, having a dezentralized network approach (funded by German government).

entry.title: Beyond Vectors: The Next Evolution of RAG on SAP BTP using SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction

We are all familiar with Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) by now. It has become the standard architecture for bringing enterprise data to Large Language Models (LLMs). The pattern is simple: chunk your documents, create vector embeddings, and perform a similarity search.

But as we move from "Proof of Concept" to production, we are hitting a ceiling.

Standard Vector RAG is excellent at finding things that "sound like" your query (semantic similarity), but it struggles with structure and reasoning. It can tell you that "Alice works at SAP," but it often fails at multi-hop questions like "Who works in the same department as the person who wrote the Q3 report?"

This is where GraphRAG enters the picture. And the best part? If you are on SAP BTP, you already have one of the most powerful engines for this architecture: SAP HANA Cloud.

The Limitations of "Flat" Data

In a standard Vector Store, your data is essentially a pile of isolated chunks. When you search, you grab the top 5 chunks from the pile. You lose the context of how those chunks relate to one another.

This becomes even more critical when dealing with Multimodal Data. Real-world enterprise documents aren't just text; they are PDFs containing diagrams, flowcharts, and architecture schematics. In a standard vector process, these images are often ignored or separated from the text that explains them.

The Solution: Hybrid GraphRAG

The next evolution of AI on SAP BTP isn't about choosing between Vector Search or Knowledge Graphs. It is about using both. I have been exploring a "Hybrid" approach where we use:

  1. The Vector Engine (built into SAP HANA Cloud) for fuzzy, semantic search.

  2. The Graph Engine (RDF/SPARQL in SAP HANA Cloud) for precise, structured relationships.

Imagine SAP HANA Cloud as a "Super Librarian." It has a messy pile of fuzzy ideas (Vectors) and a neat corkboard of connected facts (The Knowledge Graph). To answer a complex business question, the system checks the fuzzy pile to understand the intent, but validates the answer against the corkboard to ensure factual accuracy.

Multimodal RAG: Keeping Context Intact

One of the most exciting capabilities of this hybrid approach is handling mixed media.

When processing complex documentation (like technical manuals or financial reports), we can use the graph to create structural links. We can index a diagram or an image not just by what is inside it, but by where it sits in the document.

By modeling the document structure in the Knowledge Graph (e.g., TextChunk A -> ADJACENT_TO -> Image B), we ensure that when an LLM retrieves the text explanation, it automatically pulls the relevant diagram along with it. This creates a true Multimodal RAG experience that "sees" the document the way a human does.

Why SAP HANA Cloud?

Usually, building this architecture requires a complex stack: a vector database (like Pinecone), a graph database (like Neo4j), and a relational database to glue them together.

SAP HANA Cloud is unique because it is truly multi-model (yes it's also multimodal with this library). You can store your vectors, your RDF triples, and your relational metadata all in the same persistence layer. This simplifies the architecture immensely and reduces data movement, which is critical for enterprise security and latency.

A New Framework for SAP Developers

To prove this concept, I have developed a TypeScript framework designed specifically for Node.js environments on SAP BTP. It acts as a bridge, orchestrating the interaction between the LLM (via LiteLLM) and SAP HANA Cloud’s dual engines.

The framework handles:

  • Schema-Guided Extraction: Using LLMs to turn unstructured text into clean Knowledge Graph entities (Nodes and Edges).

  • Hybrid Retrieval: Performing a vector search and then traversing the graph to find related context (including images).

  • Unified Storage: Managing both the REAL_VECTOR data and RDF Triples in a single connection.

Learn More

If you are interested in building the next generation of context-aware AI agents on SAP BTP, I invite you to read the full technical breakdown here (collaboration on the repo welcome!):

👉 Read the full article on Medium: Beyond Vectors - Building Powerful Graph RAG on SAP BTP

Let’s move beyond simple similarity search and start building AI that truly understands the structure of our enterprise data.

entry.title: SAP BTP - Integration Suite: Clean Architecture vs. The Frankenstein Landscape
entry.content:
Spoiler

Disclaimer: This article shares architectural lessons learned from real-world projects. It does not promote or discourage any specific vendor; the focus is on platform coherence, governance, long-term maintainability, and a homogeneous integration landscape.

I will not present negative points or direct comparisons between platforms, and any sensitive data is out of scope. The intention is to generate reflection within the audience.

I'm also not to speak about SAP BTP in its entirety, as that would be lying and is outside my area of competence and knowledge; I only explore SAP Integration Suite.

Introduction

This blog was not written based on slides or frameworks; it was based on my experience over several years since the emergence of SAP BTP and the consolidation of the SAP Integration Suite component.

Here I will present some truths from the thinking of an out-of-the-box SAP XI/PI/PO/CPI developer. I will present 3 scenarios; I do not see much sense in more than that, it will already be enough for the integration audience to understand what I am trying to explain, or guide, or look for a point of reflection.

When I talk about “thinking outside the box,” I am not using a trendy term. I mean that if we limit ourselves to being mere technical executors of tickets—whether in PI/PO or in SAP Integration Suite SAP CPI—we will lose the overall vision of the whole. If our vision is reduced to connecting boxes, creating mappings, or writing pieces of code in Groovy or JavaScript, XML to JSON or JSON to XML conversion, we will be underutilizing both the platform and not exploring the full knowledge we have in between the external world and the SAP backend (ECC or S/4HANA – on-prem or on-cloud).

Think big, think high, do not be afraid to express your opinion.

You can start by strengthening your arguments: leverage your technical expertise to bridge cloud agility with on-premise stability. There is no reason to be left out of architectural decisions. Often, mistakes happen precisely when we "close our eyes" to the solution design and focus solely on delivering code.

Mastering what the SAP BTP - Integration Suite actually offers, you gain the authority to talk eye-to-eye with architects and help build an environment that actually makes sense

This blog is not an attack. It is an invitation to upskilling, grow and lefts the idea only connect dots, mappings and connections, we are important soldiers in this ecosystem.

Let’s go to our interesting journey.

How I saw some Frankenstein architectures being born: three real cases

Throughout my career, I witnessed moments when tools “with more know-how” ended up complicating what should have been simple. Let’s be sincere and honest here: any platform or application, whether SAP or non-SAP, always has strengths and weaknesses. However, the benefits of homogenizing these architectures are very strong: lower customization, better support, unified teams.

Scenario 1: Wasted Potential

I must confess that in this first scenario, I really saw myself only as an SAP PI/PO/CPI consultant connecting little boxes, mappings, and others. I did not have the knowledge or the courage at that time to express my position, and I believe this may have worsened the definitions, but I took a lesson from it.

Everything was organized: rules, standards, development guidelines, design, and models. At the beginning of a migration to S/4HANA, external architects ignored what was already implemented. SAP BTP (SAP Integration Suite – APIM and CPI) already existed, but they chose to neglect the investment or any larger decision and used only the minimum necessary.

APIM was completely excluded and SAP CPI was limited to standard pre-content packages with the minimum possible modification; another market platform took over the entire APIM framework and custom integrations. The result? The erosion of a strategy that was already winning.

Negative impacts:

  • Redundancy and Duplicate Costs: Maintenance of two integration platforms (BTP and a third-party tool) to perform functions that SAP Integration Suite was already designed to handle natively.
  • Operational Inefficiency: Managing security, logs, and monitoring in two different environments increases the workload of the teams.
  • Loss of Native Optimization: By ignoring the APIM layer and the full potential of CPI, the organization loses the ability to govern, and the ecosystem becomes increasingly difficult to govern.

Scenario 2: Imposition of External Architecture Patterns

I’ve consulted with Solution Architects on this specific pattern, and the consensus is that it’s far from ideal. Unfortunately, due to the project timeline and budget constraints, we aren't in a position to overhaul it. That said, I did manage to optimize some IFlows previously built by an external firm. I replaced a particularly redundant exception mechanism where data stores were being used to hold mapping results—a process that added no real value

In this case, a “three-layer architecture – Intelligence Layer, Processing/Routing Layer, Delivery Layer” borrowed from a completely different ecosystem was imposed on SAP CPI. To keep this artificial construction standing, the solution turned into a tangle of hundreds of JMS queues.

Negative impacts:

  • Unnecessary Complexity and Latency: Each extra JMS hop adds processing overhead and potential failure points that would not exist in a flow optimized for CPI.
  • High Maintenance Debt: Troubleshooting requires tracing messages through dozens of queues, making root-cause analysis extremely difficult and slow.
  • Resource and Cost Exhaustion: Excessive use of JMS queues can lead to resource bottlenecks in the tenant, affecting the performance of other critical integrations and the high operational cost of keeping this complex structure running.

Scenario 3: Fragmented Teams and Tools

Due to the strict governance and the rigid nature of the project structure, I decided to remain silent on the matter.

An organization adopted BTP in a fragmented way, using events and APIs; only SAP CPI was consolidated and very well structured in its usage. They split responsibilities among teams that did not communicate with each other. In the end, they increased costs and complexity, wasting the natural synergy of SAP BTP – SAP Integration Suite.

Negative impacts:

  • Logic and Data in Silos: Without communication, teams frequently rebuild similar logic or connectors, leading to inconsistent data mappings in the same landscape.
  • Architectural Inconsistency: Different teams apply different security and naming standards, resulting in a “patchwork” ecosystem that is difficult to govern.
  • Integration Friction: The lack of synergy prevents the organization from effectively leveraging Event-Driven Architecture (EDA).

The Rise of Fragmented Integration Architectures (“Frankenstein” Patterns)

I have seen organizations invest heavily in SAP BTP, only to leave these strategic assets idle while external tools, patterns, and “borrowed architectures” are stitched together into what I call Frankenstein Architectures, where I already provided three examples I experienced: powerful in isolation, fragile together.

These environments rarely arise from a technical necessity; more often, they emerge from disconnected decisions, architectural bias coming from professionals less familiar with SAP integration ecosystems, or lack of communication with the front line—developers specialized in SAP Integration Suite—or from uncritical reuse or following market trends that platform X or Y is better here or there, comparing applications instead of seeing homogeneity and the benefits for the final customer, thus using architectures designed for completely different ecosystems.

I am not saying it cannot be done or should not be done; different ecosystems can coexist as long as it is in a harmonious way. But when we talk about native integrations, add-ons, connectors, and others, SAP BTP – SAP Integration Suite is definitely unbeatable when the backend is SAP, whether ECC or S/4HANA.

 

Figure 1: Frankenstein Architecture

The “Legacy Mindset” Trap: The True Obstacle to Innovation

We can discuss tools, vendors, and platforms all day long, but very little of this is really limited by technology. The biggest barrier between us and a good innovation experience is habit — based on years developing legacy systems (“we will not touch it, it is working, who developed it already left the company, there is no documentation”), stable but rigid architectures, with familiar but inflexible experiences, and primitive fears of change.

Many companies still think with the logic of on-premise integration landscapes from a decade ago. This mindset generates frustration: fear of the new, discomfort with unfamiliar paradigms, and, in most cases, a fundamental lack of technical understanding of what modern platforms really offer.

Treating SAP CPI as if it were an on-premise PI/PO is not a technological limitation, but a mindset limitation. When cloud-native services become only point replacements for legacy runtimes, their true potential is never reached.

Real innovation does require a mindset change. The question should no longer be “How do I create this mapping?”, but instead:
“Should this be a mapping? Should it be an event? An API? Or should it even exist in its current form?”

Without this transition, organizations repeat historical patterns in new terrain, bringing the limitations of the past into today’s technologies. The result is not modernization, but legacy running in the cloud.

The Voice of the SAP Integration Suite Consultant: You Are the Integration Bridge

An experienced, senior, or specialist integration consultant, with knowledge in EM / EAM / APIM / IA / CPI, should not be just a ticket executor or focused exclusively on project delivery. We must act as strategic advisors. Our responsibility is to position ourselves — not to complain, but to help architects and business stakeholders make better decisions.

When technical expertise aligns with business objectives, ISA-M (Integration Solution Advisory Methodology) stops being a forgotten PDF and becomes a living instrument, capable of guiding projects to success.

Beyond SAP PO: Migration to SAP CPI or Consolidating the Legacy (Snap Logic, Boomi, MuleSoft, Informatica, Microsoft web Methods)

Many companies deal with a "Frankenstein" of middleware's. The challenge of migrating 1,000+ interfaces from Snap Logic, MuleSoft, Informatica, Dell Boomi, or web Methods or etc to SAP BTP - SAP Integration Suite is not just a technical mapping exercise—it is a functional one.

Let's imagine the perspective of a migration from SAP PI/PO to CPI. How many of you have experienced mappings filled with UDFs, field-to-field mappings with several standard functions attached (remove context, collapse context, if, else, etc.), followed by a Java mapping and an adapter module doing something else entirely?

When dealing with such mappings and modules, if you use the SAP Migration Assessment, you will likely see a status of "non-migratable." A senior integration consultant will certainly be capable of migrating them, but is it worth the time to perform reverse engineering, extract production payloads, and conduct manual tests just to see if the result is as expected?

Where is the documentation? The person who built or designed this interface—have they already left the company?

Instead of just thinking about migrating, why not think about rebuilding, analyzing, and tackling the challenge using the native capabilities of the SAP Integration Suite? Some could become events, others could be simple APIs, and so on.

Now, if migrating from SAP PI/PO to SAP CPI is challenging, imagine when it involves a third-party interface; the situation gets even worse, I'm sure of it.

 

 Figure 2: SAP Integration Consultants

Dismantling the Frankenstein Architecture

We have already gone through several topics; now I would like to enter a topic that can help a lot, from a major SAP partner where one of its co-owners is one of the biggest influencers and who contributed for years to the SCN community, @MichalKrawczyk

Let’s talk about INT4 Shield, a tool that can help your company get out of this tangle of applications, the disconnected ecosystem that can be characterized as a Frankenstein architecture.

The Int4 Suite (previously known as Int4 IFTT/Shield) is a test automation and service virtualization tool designed specifically for SAP ecosystems. It acts as an “accelerator” to dismantle the Frankenstein architecture and simplify complex migrations.

Image 3 – Dismantling the Frankenstein Architecture

To bring integrations from external platforms back to SAP BTP, or migration from SAP PI/PO, the biggest fear is functional regression (breaking what already works).

Third-Party Virtualization: Int4 Shield can simulate the responses of those “external platforms” that today hold the APIM framework and custom integrations. This allows you to develop on SAP BTP and test the end-to-end flow without needing the external system to be ready or available.
Parity Guarantee: You can capture the behavior of the external platform and validate whether the new implementation on SAP Integration Suite delivers exactly the same result, ensuring that the original “winning” strategy is restored without operational risks.

PI/PO Migration: The End of Manual Reverse Engineering

The scenario of migrating UDFs (User Defined Functions) and complex Java mappings without documentation is one of the biggest time and cost bottlenecks. Int4 Shield addresses exactly these points:

Payload Capture Automation

Instead of a consultant needing to manually extract payloads from production (which involves security and compliance risks), Int4 Shield automates the capture of real messages from the PI/PO production or QA environment. It creates a “test case repository” based on real business data.

Comparative Tests (Side-by-Side)

Int4 Shield executes the mapping in the old PI/PO and, simultaneously, the new mapping in SAP Integration Suite (BTP).

  • Automatic Comparison: It compares the output XML/JSON of both. If there is a difference of a single cent or character due to a complex UDF, the tool points out exactly where the error is.
  • No Reverse Engineering: The consultant does not need to understand every line of legacy Java code. They need to ensure that Output A (Legacy) is equal to Output B (BTP). Int4 Shield validates this massively, testing hundreds of scenarios in minutes.

Resource and Time Reduction

  • Elimination of Manual Testing: The effort to manually test complex mappings is reduced by up to 80%.
  • Independence from Documentation: As the tool uses the real message behavior as the “absolute truth,” the lack of UDF documentation is no longer a critical blocker.

Summary of Technological Benefits

Manual ChallengeSolution with Int4 Shield
Payload ExtractionAutomated and secure capture of real messages.
UDFs/Java MappingsValidation by result comparison (Black-box testing).
Reverse EngineeringFocus on the final result, not the old code.
Frankenstein ArchitectureSecure validation of migration from external components to BTP.

SAP ISA-M (Integration Solution Advisory Methodology):

This is not just a document; it’s your compass for homogenization. It ensures that every integration choice follows a standard, preventing the "Frankenstein" effect by defining exactly when to use an API, an event, or a file.

  • SAP APIM + SAP CPI: Stop putting everything inside Cloud Integration. Use APIM for security and governance.

  • SAP AEM + S/4HANA: Move from polling to real-time events with Advanced Event Mesh.

  • B2B Governance: Use Trading Partner Management (TPM) so EDI flows aren't "black boxes."

RISE with SAP and Clean Core: The Last Chance to Fix the Past

The RISE with SAP methodology is not only a path to move the backend to S/4HANA — it represents a rare opportunity to rethink historical decisions, clean up excesses, and correct distortions that accumulated over the years. When we talk about Clean Core, the focus usually falls almost exclusively on the backend: excessive ABAP Z, direct core modifications, custom logic created to address momentary urgencies that became permanent.

This effort is correct, necessary, and inevitable, but there is a critical point that often stays out of the equation: the integration layer.

If the company is willing to revisit decades of customized developments in SAP ECC or S/4HANA, why not apply the same principle to the integration architecture?

Integration is not optional. It is essential for the business to function. It is where processes connect, data flows, partners integrate, and critical operations happen in real time.

Ignoring this layer during a RISE initiative is losing half of the transformation value.

The Clean Core concept should not stop at ABAP. It needs to extend to how integrations are designed, governed, and evolved. Keeping the core clean while fragmenting integration with multiple external tools, borrowed architectures, and misaligned standards creates a paradox: a modern backend supported by a chaotic integration.

SAP Integration Suite, within the SAP BTP ecosystem, exists exactly to absorb this complexity outside the core. APIs, events, message-oriented integrations, and B2B were designed so that the backend remains stable, standardized, and ready for continuous evolution. Breaking this logic, outsourcing native capabilities to external solutions without a clear strategic reason, goes in the opposite direction of what RISE and Clean Core propose.

The RISE moment is the right moment to visit, observe, and question:

  • Why does this integration exist in this way?
  • Why was this mapping created like this? Where is the documentation?
  • How are we going to migrate this tangle of integrations from SAP PI/PO, which has no documentation, to SAP CPI? Is this not the moment to evaluate what is worth migrating and what is worth rebuilding in a cleaner way?
  • Should this logic be in ABAP Z or outside the core?
  • Does this functionality already exist natively in SAP Integration Suite?
  • Are we really homogenizing the architecture or just replacing one fragmented architecture with another?

RISE with SAP offers the context, executive sponsorship, and organizational momentum that rarely happen in day-to-day work. It is exactly at this moment that structural decisions need to be made — not only in the backend, but across the entire integration landscape.

Cleaning the core and ignoring integration is an incomplete transformation. Thinking Clean Core without Clean Integration is postponing known problems to a more expensive and more complex future.

True modernization happens when backend and integration evolve together, in a coherent, governed way and aligned with the business strategy.

Image 3 – Rise and Clean core backend plus Integration refactoring

 

Spoiler
Disclaimer: The views expressed in this article are based on personal professional experience and do not represent SAP, its partners, or any affiliated organization.

Conclusion

I hope this reflection encourages Integration Consultants to think outside the box. It is vital that we are involved in strategic decisions and the application of the SAP ISA-M (Integration Solution Advisory Methodology).

We must act as strategic advisors, not just ticket executors. Our responsibility is to help architects and stakeholders make better decisions. Your opinion is not just a technical preference; it is a vital contribution to long-term maintainability. When we understand the full potential of the platform, we stop being "box connectors" and become the architects of a truly connected, clean future.

Remember, we are soldiers on the front line, and the integration layer is of vital importance to the company. Why not become a general, with years of practical experience in your hands? Think about it.

Thank you.

entry.title: Accessing SAP BTP Core Services APIs Using SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS)
entry.content:
Accessing SAP Cloud Integration (SAP CI) information programmatically has become quite common today.
Whether it’s iFlows, message processing logs, or deployed artifacts, SAP CI OData APIs make this information easily available, all we need is SAP CI technical user with the right roles.

This convenience often raises a natural question:

Can we do the same for SAP BTP as well?

Can we programmatically access:

  • SAP BTP account details ?
  • Subaccounts and entitlements ?
  • Services and runtime information ?

The answer is Yes, but unlike SAP CI, the authentication and access model for SAP BTP Core Services is fundamentally different.

 

Why SAP BTP Is Different from SAP CI?

When accessing SAP CI OData APIs, authentication is straightforward:

  • Use an SAP CI technical user
  • Assign the required roles
  • Call the OData endpoint

However, SAP BTP Core Services APIs (Accounts, Entitlements, Directories, etc.) do not work this way.

One cannot:

  • Use SAP CI technical users
  • Use basic authentication
  • Directly call these APIs without a management service
SAP BTP protects these APIs using OAuth 2.0 and requires a dedicated management service to act as a trusted client.
And this is exactly where the SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS) comes into play.
 

Introducing SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS)

To access SAP BTP Core Services APIs, SAP mandates the use of: SAP Cloud Management Service – CIS plan

CIS acts as:

  • An authorized OAuth client
  • A secure gateway to SAP BTP management APIs
  • The mechanism through which access tokens are issued for Core Services

Once CIS is configured, SAP Cloud Integration can securely access SAP BTP Core Services APIs.

 

Create SAP Cloud Management Service Instance

Step 1: BTP Cockpit --> Subaccount --> Service Marketplace --> Search “CIS”

Step 2: Create an instance of CIS using the three dots present on the top right of the tile.

Pick “central-viewer” as the plan and click on create

You can check the scope of each plan here : SAP Cloud Management Service - Service Plans | SAP Help Portal
Once this step is done, CIS will be available in the Instances column of the subaccount.

Step 3: Now create a Service key for this instance.

As soon as service key is created ServiceKey cis.json file is ready for the download.

The JSON looks like this :

Among the endpoints in the above picture, our focus is on the endpoint, which will give us the details related to SAP BTP Account.

"accounts_service_url": "https://accounts-service.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com"

Now to access this URL, we need to setup OAuth 2.0 Credentials on SAP CI using the details provided in this JSON file.

 

Setting up OAuth 2.0 Credentials on SAP CI

Refer the JSON file and configure the security artifact as shown below.

Token Service URL : <<uaa_url>>/oauth/token
Client ID : << clientid >>
Client Secret : << clientsecret >>
Custom Parameters : grantType : clientCredentials
 

SAP CI Iflow:

We have all the configuration in place, now the most interesting part, lets deploy and test the flow.

HTTP Adapter Configurations:

Base URL: https://accounts-service.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com (can be found in the JSON file)
Resource to fetch information of Global Account: /accounts/v1/globalAccount 

Address: https://accounts-service.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/accounts/v1/globalAccount

Other resources of this API can be found here https://api.sap.com/package/SAPCloudPlatformCoreServices/rest

Credentails Name: As created above

Conclusion:

SAP BTP Core Services APIs follow a different and more secure access model. These APIs are protected using OAuth 2.0 and require the SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS) as the authorized gateway.

Once CIS is configured, consuming SAP BTP Core Services APIs from SAP Cloud Integration becomes seamless, enabling automation, governance, and platform-level insights. Understanding this distinction is essential for designing robust and future-ready integration scenarios on SAP BTP.
